entry.title: Entendiendo la Extensibilidad en SAP Cloud ERP: Parte 3
entry.content:
Como vimos en los primeros dos blogs Parte 1 y Parte 2, extender SAP Cloud ERP (o com√∫nmente llamado SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition), es muy importante para adaptarse a la necesidad espec√≠fica de cada uno de tus clientes.

SAP Cloud ERP puede extenderse dentro de si misma, pero en esta parte final, abordaremos una de las formas √≥ptimas de escalar tu soluci√≥n y es, mediante el uso de la SAP Business Technology Platform o SAP BTP, mediante el dise√±o de aplicaciones Multi-tenant y multi-backend, para esto tenemos varios ejemplos dentro de los recursos oficiales de SAP, pero quiero mostrarles el que para m√≠, es el m√°s relevante para quienes desean comenzar en SAP Cloud ERP y tienen ya pr√°cticas en otro de nuestros productos, como SAP Business One o SAP Business ByDesign.

 

 

 

Proceso de desarrollo para un cliente a m√∫ltiples tenants y diferentes Back-ends

Empecemos an√°lizando lo siguiente: en tu empresa tienen una necesidad clara y deciden desarrollar una aplicaci√≥n espec√≠fica para un cliente, para ello puedes crearla directamente In-App, usando por ejemplo Key-user o Developer Extensibility en Cloud ERP.

Como segundo an√°lisis, quiero que revisemos lo que pasa, si te das cuenta que esa necesidad es la misma para otros usuarios, el camino entonces, es pensar en una soluci√≥n multi-tenant, que de hecho puede ser desarrollada dentro de SAP Cloud ERP, usando por ejemplo la Multi-off Delivery o la Scalable Delivery.

Ahora como tercer an√°lisis, ¬øqu√© pasa si te das cuenta que esa aplicaci√≥n no solo es √∫til para clientes de SAP Cloud ERP?, sino que tienes clientes de SAP Business One, SAP Business ByDesign, o incluso deseas poner la aplicaci√≥n como standalone solution y permitir el acceso a clientes que no cuentan con una de nuestras ERPs. All√≠ se hace muy relevante escalar nuestra aplicaci√≥n y usar la SAP BTP como centro de desarrollo y despliegue, nos referimos entonces a una aplicaci√≥n Multi-tenant y Multi-backend o de ERP agn√≥stico.

 

 

Modelos Operacionales

 

Como partner puedes tener diferentes modelos operacionales, uno de ellos es el modelo ‚ÄúCustomer Managed‚Äù donde los clientes gestionan directamente la implementaci√≥n y el mantenimiento de las soluciones, con el apoyo t√©cnico y consultoria del Partner.

Otro modelo es el ‚ÄúPartner SaaS Solutions‚Äù, donde el Partner desarrolla y gestiona aplicaciones de software como servicio (SaaS) en la nube, utilizando la plataforma SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). Este modelo permite a los Partners ofrecer soluciones escalables y compatibles con las actualizaciones de SAP ERP, proporcionando a los clientes acceso a aplicaciones avanzadas y servicios como inteligencia artificial y machine Learning.

 

 

Partner Reference App: el caso de uso

 

La BTP Partner Reference App es un modelo, que te permite crear aplicaciones directamente en la SAP BTP, dise√±adas para ser compatibles con las actualizaciones de SAP Cloud ERP, lo cual deja como resultado: f√°cil integraci√≥n y mantenimiento de la misma. Incluye ventajas de compatibilidad y eficiencia. El link general de esta aplicaci√≥n se encuentra publicado en nuestro GitHub  (BTP Partner Reference App).

La BTP Partner Reference app, sigue el modelo de soluciones de Software como Servicio para nuestros Partners. Al estar alojada en la SAP BTP est√° clasificada como una Side-by-side Extension, este tipo de aplicaciones son operadas desde esta plataforma y cuentan con ciclo de vida propio, independiente del ERP que se use.

Esta aplicaci√≥n es un imaginario de un Poetry Slam, donde el usuario debe imaginar que es un manager de eventos, quien organiza eventos de poes√≠a, y usa la aplicaci√≥n para planear y ejecutar los eventos, analizar los costos, comprar equipo, publicar los eventos, manejar las reservas, los visitantes y artistas.

 

Este modelo, sigue los est√°ndares SAP, con un modelo centralizado de identidad y autenticaci√≥n, un Launchpad com√∫n, navegaci√≥n entre aplicaciones y una integraci√≥n back-end segura. Tienes dos formas de acceder a esta aplicaci√≥n y probarla por ti mismo: la primera es ir directamente y clonar el repositorio de Github, o seguir paso a paso desde el desarrollo inicial hasta el modelo final. Si sigues el segundo paso la gu√≠a te llevar√° a:

 

1.     Crear el Core: donde el foco es la l√≥gica, los roles, los modelos y el contenido.

2.     Make it scale: all√≠ entender√°s como pasar de una soluci√≥n para un cliente a una multi-tenant

3.     Connect: Integra la soluci√≥n con tu ERP preferida

4.     Features: Agrega nuevas funcionalidades, a√±ade servicios, integra con elementos de terceros.

 

 

Tipo de Aplicaciones que pueden seguir este modelo

Pero ¬øC√≥mo saber qu√© tipo de aplicaciones pueden seguir este modelo?, aconsejamos este tipo de extensi√≥n cuando:

-    Son aplicaciones para un grupo separado de usuarios (Usuarios sin ERP)

-    Aplicaciones que deben tener proximidad a SAP BTP para el aprovechamiento de servicios como Machine Learning, AI entre otros.

-    Soluciones que deben ser integradas con diferentes ERPs y servicios en la nube.

 

 

Ventajas de este tipo de aplicaciones

¬øQu√© ventajas tienen este tipo de aplicaciones principalmente?

-    SAP standard para el desarrollo, experiencia de usuario y dise√±o

-    Mantener el Clean Core, que te permite acelerar la innovaci√≥n y estar siempre al d√≠a con actualizaciones.

-    Incluir Herramientas de Inteligencia artificial en tus soluciones.

 

 

Partner Journeys posibles

Seguir este modelo de arquitectura, permite tener un dise√±o que apoye diferentes caminos como Partners:

-    Un Partner de SAP Cloud ERP, puede crear IP que extienda la soluci√≥n

-    Un Partner Business One puede extender su negocio a SAP Cloud ERP

-    Un Partner ByD puede extender su soluci√≥n e IP a SAP Cloud ERP

-    Un Service Partner, puede crear una soluci√≥n escalable que por ejemplo provea a una gran compa√±√≠a con servicios a m√∫ltiples departamentos y subsidiarias.

 

 

Integraci√≥n con SAP Cloud ERP

 

 

Para la integraci√≥n con SAP Cloud ERP, es importante configurar el SAP Cloud Identity Services, y en la BTP el acceso de Trust Management, los servicios de Destino, entre otros servicios necesarios. Por el lado de SAP Cloud ERP, se deben configurar todos los canales de comunicaci√≥n, como Communication arrangement, Communication System, etc. , agregar la aplicaci√≥n como un ‚Äúcustom tile‚Äù y poder acceder a ella. 

El dise√±o de esta aplicaci√≥n permite la integraci√≥n en dos lineas, la primera Front-end que le permite navegar a la Aplicaci√≥n Poetry Slam Manager a los proyectos espec√≠ficos conectados en SAP Cloud ERP, y la integraci√≥n Back-end que permite crear un proyecto en SAP Cloud ERP y visualizarlo dentro de la aplicaci√≥n side-by-side mediante OData APis con el uso del principio de propagaci√≥n.

 

 

Extender tu aplicaci√≥n

En la √∫ltima versi√≥n de este ejemplo, tambi√©n se muestra la opci√≥n de adaptar este tipo de aplicaci√≥n para clientes espec√≠ficos, ya que hemos visto que aunque sea una soluci√≥n que resuelva un Problema de muchos clientes, cada cliente tiene sus propias necesidades y adaptarla tambi√©n genera robustez en la soluci√≥n.

Al ser una Cloud Application Programming model, o CAP, tambi√©n se pueden extender:

-    Campos

-    Entidades

-    Aplicaciones Web

-    APIs

 

 

Alcance del mercado al dise√±ar Multi-tenancy y ERP Agnogstic

Al aprovechar el dise√±o multitenant y ERP agnogstic, como partner de SAP, puedes aumentar significativamente el alcance del mercado. Este tipo de dise√±o permite que una sola instancia de aplicaci√≥n sirva a multiples tenants, lo que implica soluciones escalables y rentables a m√°s clientes, con la posibilidad de compartir servicios y disminuir costos. Adem√°s el dise√±o agn√≥stico, asegura que la aplicaci√≥n pueda ser f√°cilmente integrada a diferentes ERPs, no solo con los de SAP aumentando el atractivo de este tipo de aplicaciones y utilidad en diferentes entornos de clientes. Este enfoque mejora la penetraci√≥n del mercado y abre oportunidades para entregar soluciones a m√°s clientes independiente de la estructura ERP existente.

 

En estos tres blogs y en espa√±ol :P, hemos recorrido las diversas opciones para extender SAP Cloud ERP, destacando la importancia y las diversas formas de adaptar esta soluci√≥n a las necesidades de tus clientes. Espero que esta informaci√≥n haya sido √∫til y te haya proporcionado una visi√≥n clara de como escalar tus soluciones.

 

Me encantar√≠a saber que te pareci√≥ esta serie, Gracias por leerme.

Integrating SAP EHS in the Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side ‚Äì Guidebook

1. Introduction: Why Extensibility Matters in EHS Implementations

Implementing SAP Environment, Health & Safety (EHS) in the Public Cloud provides customers with a powerful set of standard capabilities across EHS functionality such as Incident Management, Risk Management, or Emissions Management. However, real-life EHS processes often include country-specific regulations, industry-dependent reporting obligations, and customer-individual workflows that cannot always be covered by the standard product alone. This is where extensibility becomes a critical success factor.

From our project experience, we see that nearly every EHS implementation requires selected adaptations ‚Äì whether to incorporate local legal requirements, enrich analytics, adjust incident forms, or create custom validations. With SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and SAP EHS, such enhancements must follow SAP‚Äôs clean-core principles, meaning they must be implemented using the officially supported extensibility technologies.

This blog post provides a clear, practical overview of the extensibility options available for SAP EHS in the Public Cloud and demonstrates how they can be applied to real-world scenarios.

1.1 What You Can Expect from This Blog Post

In this part, we outline the extensibility landscape for EHS Public Cloud and guide you through:

  • Which extensibility options exist in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • How they apply specifically to EHS use cases
  • Which BAdIs are available and when to use them
  • Concrete examples for extensibility
  • Best practices based on our project experience

The aim is to give implementation teams a practical understanding of how to adapt the system without breaking the clean core, ensuring long-term upgradeability and compliance.

1.2 Why Extensibility is Especially Important for EHS

From our project experience, EHS is one of the most extensibility-driven domains in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud because:

  • Regulations differ significantly by country (e.g. OSHA, EU directives, etc.)
  • Incident reports must reflect local legal requirements
  • Customers require tailored analytics and KPIs
  • Integration with external safety systems is common
  • Forms and regulatory outputs often need custom structures

EHS processes must adapt to organizational legal, and operational needs. Extensibility in Public Cloud ensures this adaptability without compromising SAP‚Äôs clean-core principles.

 

2. Extensibility Options in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides a comprehensive extensibility portfolio designed to support innovation without compromising the stability of the core system. These capabilities range from low-code configuration tools for business users to pro-code development environments for technical teams. Understanding these options is essential for designing scalable, future-proof EHS solutions ‚Äì especially in Public Cloud environments where clean-core principles are mandatory.

Extensibility Portfolio for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Own illustration based on SAP source: https://www.sap.com/documents/2018/05/606d1ee8-037d-0010-87a3-c30de2ffd8ff.html)

2.1 Low-Code vs. Pro-Code Extensibility

The extensibility portfolio is structured along two axes:

  • Low-Code: Target at key user and functional experts who need to quickly adapt user interfaces, create fields, or adjust logic without deep technical development.
  • Pro-Code: Designed for professional developers who require advanced capabilities through the ABAP Cloud development model or SAP BTP services.

These options are distributed across two major extensibility categories: On-Stack Extensibility (In-App) & Side-by-Side Extensibility.

2.2 On-Stack Extensibility (In-App)

Executed directly inside SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, following the clean-core principles enforced by SAP.

Key User & Developer Extensibility

2.2.1 Key User Extensibility (Low-Code)

Accessible directly via the SAP Fiori Launchpad, key user extensibility enables business focused adjustments such as:

  • UI adaptation mode: Modify screen layouts, hide/show fields, rearrange sections.
  • Custom fields: Create and publish custom fields that automatically extend UI, APIs, CDS views, and reports.
  • Custom logic (using BAdIs or BDEF extensions): Implement small logic enhancements using predefined extensions points.
  • Custom business objects: Model simple new business objects without coding.
  • Custom CDS views & OData services: Build analytical and integration-ready views with drag-and-drop tooling.
  • Analytical queries and applications: Extend reporting and KPIs in SAP Fiori or SAP Analytics Cloud.

Key User Extensibility is ideal for EHS teams that need to adapt processes quickly, e.g. adding a regulatory field in Incident Management or creating country-specific reporting structures.

2.2.2 Developer Extensibility (Pro-Code)

Developer Extensibility is performed using ABAP Cloud in Eclipse via ABAP Development Tools (ADT), enabling professional developers to build upgrade-safe extensions inside the SAP S/4HANA Cloud stack.

Typical capabilities include:

  • UI adaptation projects via SAP Business Application Studio
  • Extension fields built using professional ABAP development tools
  • Custom logic (BAdIs and BDEF extensions) with advanced editor capabilities
  • RAP Business Objects (full-fledge RESTful ABAP applications)
  • CDS views and OData services with full development tooling
  • Analytical queries and custom analytical content

This level of extensibility is used when EHS implementations require more complex data models, multi-step validations, or custom processes beyond the key user scope.

2.3 Side-by-Side Extensibility

When requirements cannot be fulfilled within the S/4HANA Cloud stack, SAP BTP provides a powerful platform for building complementary applications:

  • SAP Build Apps (no-code mobile and web apps)
  • SAP Build Process Automation (workflows and automations)
  • SAP Build Work Zone (custom dashboard and portals)
  • SAP Build Code / CAP (cloud-native pro-code development, Node.js/Java)
  • ABAP Environment on BTP (Steampunk) for ABAP Cloud side-by-side extensions

Side-by-side extensibility is particularly relevant for EHS when:

  • complex mobile solutions are required (e.g. hazard observations, audits)
  • workflow automation or robotic processing is desired
  • large-scale integration scenarios (e.g., IoT sensors, safety systems) are needed
  • custom employee or contractor portals must be built

Although side-by-side extensibility plays an important role in the overall SAP extensibility strategy, we will not dive deeper into BTP-based extensions in this blog post. Our objective is to demonstrate what can be achieved directly within the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, using standard in-app extensibility options that remain fully aligned with SAP‚Äôs clean-core principles. Based on our project experience, most EHS related enhancements such as custom fields, logic, reporting extensions, and form adaptations can be delivered efficiently using Key User or Developer Extensibility (on-stack). For this reason, the upcoming chapters focus exclusively on in-app, upgrade-safe extensibility scenarios that can be implemented without additional BTP architecture.

2.4 BAdIs in the Public Cloud (Key User vs. Developer Access)

Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) are predefined extension points provided by SAP that allow injecting custom logic while staying upgrade safe. You can explore the available BAdIs for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud here: Business Add-Ins | SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) | SAP Business Accelerator Hub

There are two categories in S/4HANA Public Cloud:

Key User BAdIs

  • Implemented through the Custom Logic SAP Fiori app
  • Available only for selected business contexts
  • Designed for simple enhancements such as: Validation rules, Derivation of field values, Basic calculations

Developer BAdIs

  • Implemented using ABAP Development Tools (ADT) in SAP BTP ABAP Environment or Embedded Steampunk
  • Allow more complex coding scenarios
  • Enable interaction with APIs, CDS views, RAP BOs and advanced data handling

In EHS specifically, SAP provides a growing set of BAdIs ‚Äì particularly in Incident Management and Emissions Management ‚Äì which are essential for country specific reporting, custom form generation, or regulatory compliance.

The following list provides an overview of the EHS-specific BAdIs that are currently available in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Incident Management

  • BAdI: Change of Field Values in BG (Berufsgenossenschaft) Incident Report (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Incident Basic Information (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Custom Field Incident Data (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Involved Person Data (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Incident Root Data (Key User)

Risk Management

  • (No BAdIs available for Risk Management in Public Cloud yet)

Emissions Management

  • BAdI: Field Control for Extension of Amount Root (Key User)
  • BAdI: Check Amounts State and Perform Subsequent Actions (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Generation of Export Files (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Compliance Requirement Import from XLSX (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection Import (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection Import from XLSX BAdI (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection XLSX Parser BAdI (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Field Control for Extension of Data Collection Root (Key User)

As the overview shows, the currently available BAdIs for EHS in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud are primarily focused on Key User Extensibility, especially within Incident Management and Emissions Management. While Developer Extensibility via ABAP Cloud provides a more advanced pro-code extension model, the current EHS-specific enhancement points are mostly delivered as in-app, low-code BAdIs to ensure upgrade stability and full alignment with SAP‚Äôs clean core principles.

This corresponds closely with our experience from project implementations: Most EHS extension requirements can be delivered efficiently using in-app, Key User Extensibility tools such as Custom Fields, Custom Logic, UI Adaptation, and CDS View extensions without requiring developer access.

 

3. Practical Extensibility Scenarios in EHS

In chapter 2, we explored the extensibility options available in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and outlined which of these options are most relevant for EHS implementations. As highlighted, the majority of extensibility points currently exposed in the EHS area (especially within Incident Management and Emissions Management) are implemented using Key User Extensibility, including custom fields, UI adaptation, form template configuration, and Custom Logic BAdIs.

Because of this, this chapter focuses exclusively on Key User Extensibility in practice, demonstrating how customers can solve real-world EHS requirements entirely within the Public Cloud without requiring developer extensibility or SAP BTP side-by-side extensions.

Drawing from our project experience, we selected two scenarios that reflect common customer requirements:

  1. Adding custom attributes to the Incident Management process
  2. Generating a country-specific incident report, using custom form templates and multiple BAdIs

Both scenarios illustrate how far customers can go using the extensibility tools embedded in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, while fully adhering to the clean-core principle.

3.1 Example 1 - Introducing a Custom Attribute for Incident Records

Extensibility Type:

  • Key User Extensibility

Tools & Apps Used:

  • Custom Fields App (SAP Fiori App)
  • UI Adaptation (SAP Fiori Settings)

3.1.1 Business Requirement

Many organizations require an additional field ‚ÄúBusiness Unit‚Äù to be captured as part of incident documentation to meet internal reporting needs, support organizational analysis, or fulfill local compliance requirements. Since this information is not available in the standard SAP EHS Public Cloud data model, customers often need to introduce it as a custom field.

Typically, the Business Unit may be required in multiple stages of the Incident Management process, such as:

  • Incident Creation
  • Incident Processing
  • Reporting and Analytics Dashboards

In our case, the Business Unit field was only added to the Incident Processing step, primarily for simplicity and to demonstrate the extensibility approach in clear and focused manner. However, this field can be added to additional UIs and process steps as needed, depending on the customer‚Äôs specific requirements, organizational structure, or compliance obligations.

3.1.2 Step-by-Step Implementation

Create New Custom Field

In this step a custom field for the Incident Management will be created using the ‚ÄúCustom Fields‚Äù Fiori App. You can follow the steps below to create a custom field:

1. Navigate to the ‚ÄúCustom Fields‚Äù app from the Fiori Launchpad.

2. Click ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù.

3. Enter the following details:

  • Business Context: Select the relevant context (e.g. EHHSS_INC_BINFA).
  • Label: Provide a meaningful name (Business Unit). Identifier & Tooltip will be filled automatically.
  • Type: Choose from options like Text, Number, Date, etc.
  • Length: Define the size of the field if applicable.

Create New Field

After the required details have been filled, select Create and Edit.

4. Enable the fields for the relevant applications.

The fields of the tabs User Interfaces, Analytics and APIs will be enabled by default. These tabs are required to support user interactions, reporting as well as integrations for the recently added custom field (Business Unit).

Field Enablement

If the new field should appear in generated documents such as PDFs or reports, you need to enable the required Form Templates. In our scenario, two Form Templates were activated as shown below.

Enabled Form Templates

Note: The YY1_WHS_FORM10 Template is a custom Form Template. The creation of this Form Template will be shown in chapter 3.2.

5. Save and publish the custom field to make it available in the system.

 

Assign custom field to Fiori app

Custom fields created by using the ‚ÄúCustom Fields‚Äù Fiori app can be assigned to the relevant Fiori applications based on the selected business context. Follow these steps to add the field:

1. Open the ‚ÄúManage Incident‚Äù Fiori app & click on any incident.

2. Click on your profile & choose ‚ÄúAdapt UI‚Äù

Navigate to "Adapt UI"

 3. Once Adapt UI is activated, you can start customizing the page layout and add the recently created custom field to the relevant sections. By selecting ‚ÄúCustomize‚Äù > ‚ÄúShow Customizable Areas‚Äù as shown below, you will be able to insert the new custom field ‚ÄúBusiness Unit‚Äù into the desired section of the Fiori App.

Navigate to "Show Customizable Areas"

 4. Select the Customizable Area that should be changed.

Select Customizable Area

 5. Select the element as shown below & click on ‚ÄúCustomize UIBB‚Äù.

Select "Customize UIBB"

 6. To add the new field, select ‚ÄúElement‚Äù > ‚ÄúAdd Element‚Äù.

Add Element

 7. Select the recently created field YY1_BUSINESSUNIT_IBN and select ‚ÄúOK‚Äù.

Select field YY1_BUSINESSUNIT_IBN

 

In the below shown illustration you can see an example, after the Business Unit was added to the UI.

Field Business Unit added to UI

 8. Save the UI adaptation for this page.  

 

3.2 Example 2 - Generating a Country-Specific Incident Report

Extensibility Type:

  • Key User Extensibility

Tools & Apps Used:

  • Adobe Lifecycle Designer (External Tool)
  • Maintain Form Template App (SAP Fiori App)
  • Custom Logic App (SAP Fiori App)
  • CBC Configuration (SAP Public Cloud) / or if no access exists Implementation Activities (SAP Fiori App)

3.2.1 Business Requirement

In many EHS implementations, customers need to generate country-specific incident reports that comply with national legal requirements. These reports often require a combination of standard fields, people related information, and custom fields that are not provided in the SAP EHS Public Cloud standard forms. For example, organizations operating in Australia may be required to submit the WHS Form 10, a mandatory workplace health and safety report documenting incidents, injuries, or hazards in accordance with the Australian Work Health and Safety (WHS) Regulations (made-up). To support this requirement, a custom Adobe form template must be created and populated with incident data, including custom fields. This requires implementing the relevant Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) to retrieve, map, and supply the correct incident information into the custom form.

The report must include:

  • Basic incident details
  • Person and involvement information
  • Custom fields required for the local legislative format

3.2.2 Step-by-Step Implementation

Develop a Custom Form in Adobe Lifecycle Designer

A custom form template needs to be created to meet the specific requirements of the report. The form should include all necessary fields. To showcase this example, we created the form template YY1_WHS_FORM10 in Adobe Lifecycle Designer and saved it as an xdp file.

Form Template Creation in Adobe Lifecycle Designer

 

Upload Custom Form in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

Once the custom form template is created in Adobe Lifecycle Designer, the next step is to upload it to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud by using the ‚ÄúMaintain Form Template‚Äù app.

1. Open the ‚ÄúMaintain Form Template‚Äù app in your SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system.

2. Navigate to the ‚ÄúCustom Template‚Äù tab.

3. Click ‚ÄúNew‚Äù to create a new entry.

4. Enter a Form Template Name of your choice (for example ‚ÄúYY1_WHS_FORM10‚Äù including the prefix ‚ÄúYY1_‚Äù for custom forms).

5. Upload the form file that you created in Adobe Lifecycle Designer.

6. Select the Data Source Name as ‚ÄúEHSS_FDP_INCIDENT_SRV‚Äù.

The illustration below shows how the form setup was done in our scenario.

Form Setup (1)

Form Setup (2)

 

Assign Custom Fields & Custom Logic to the form

In this step we assign the created custom fields & logic to the form (shown in the previous step). This is achieved by using the ‚ÄúCustom Logic‚Äù app in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, where you can leverage the available Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) provided by the system. To retrieve the required information in the form, you can implement the following BAdIs:

  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO
  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PERS
  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT

1. Click ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù to start a new implementation.

2. Select one of the mentioned BAdIs above and proceed to ‚ÄúStep 2‚Äù (if no filters are needed jump over to step 3 and enter an Implementation Description).

3. Create and publish the Implementation.

4. Navigate to the created Implementation.

Created Implementations

 5. Select ‚ÄúCode Editor‚Äù and write ABAP logic using released APIs and CDS views.

Open Code Editor

The below shown BAdI implementation YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO retrieves incident basic information from the CDS View I_IncidentBasicInfo and populates the INCIDENTBASICINFO structure, so that key fields such as the Creation Date Time or Business Unit (which was previously created as a custom field in chapter 3.1) are available in the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO

Perform the same steps for the other required BadIs.

BAdI YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PE retrieves involved person details, such as Person‚Äôs Full Name, from the CDS View I_IncidentInvolvedPerson which makes it available in the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PE

BAdI YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT retrieves root-level incident data such as CreationDateTime from the CDS View I_Incident and makes these fields available for the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT

Note: BAdIs are essential because they supply data for custom and standard fields in the form. Without these implementations, the fields would remain empty, as the standard logic does not retrieve the required CDS view information.

6. Click ‚ÄúPublish‚Äù to implement.

 

Functional Configuration (Assign Form to regulation)

Uploading the Adobe form just makes the template available in the system. To actually use it in the EHS process, you need to specify the form and assign it to the correct form group and regulation. This ensures the form is linked to the appropriate compliance context and can be selected when generating reports.

This can be achieved by performing the mentioned steps below performed in the SAP Central Business Configuration (or ‚ÄùImplementation Activities‚Äù app).

1. Specify form: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Specify Forms

Each form entry shows key technical attributes:

  • Form Name & Form Title : Represents the form to be specified (In our scenario: WHS).
  • Form Type: Indicates the technology used for the form. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, this is typically ‚ÄúSAP Interactive Form‚Äù, which refers to Adobe-based forms used for output and reporting.
  • Form Controller: Controls the rendering and behavior of the form in SAP (In our scenario: CL_EHFND_FW_ADS_OM_FORM_CTRL).
  • Data Provider: Supplies the data from the EHS process to the form (In our scenario: CL_EHHSS_AIF_INCIDENT_DPROV).
  • Form Object Name: Identifies the form template used for output. This should match the custom form you uploaded earlier in the ‚ÄúMaintain Form Template‚Äù app (In our scenario: YY1_WHS_FORM10).

Specify Form

 2. Assign Form to the Form Group: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration  > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Specify Form Groups and Assign Forms

Assign Form to Form Group (1)

After defining the form groups, the next step is to assign the relevant specified forms to these groups. This can be performed on the second level of the selected form group and ensures that the custom or standard forms are correctly linked to the appropriate reporting or regulatory context.

Assign Form to Form Group (2)

 3. Specify Regulations & assign Regulation to Incidents: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety >  Specify Regulations.

Specify Regulations & Assign Regulation to Incidents (1)

After specifying the regulation (e.g., WHS), the next step is to assign it to the relevant incident categories. This ensures that when users select a regulation in the Incident process, the correct forms from the assigned form group become available for reporting.

Specify Regulations & Assign Regulation to Incidents (2)

 4. Assign the Forms to Regulations: Finally, link the forms to the corresponding regulation. This step ensures that when a regulation (e.g., WHS) is selected in the Incident process, the correct form becomes available for reporting.

Therefore, open the SAP Central Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Assign Forms to Regulations.

Assign Forms to Regulations

 

Generating the Report

Once the configuration is complete, you can generate the report directly from the ‚ÄúManage Incident‚Äù app.

1. Open the ‚ÄúManage Incident‚Äù app

2. Select any Incident which has the status  ‚ÄúIn Process‚Äù.

3. Click on ‚ÄúRegulations‚Äù, choose ‚ÄúWHS‚Äù, then click ‚ÄúOK‚Äù and‚Äù Save‚Äù.

Generate Report (1)

After selecting the WHS regulation, the system makes the corresponding report option available under the ‚ÄúReports‚Äù tab.

4. Navigate to the ‚ÄúReports‚Äù tab.

5. Select the WHS Report from the list.

6. Click ‚ÄúGenerate‚Äù to create the report.

Generate Report (2)

Once you click ‚ÄúGenerate‚Äù for the selected Report Type, the WHS report is created and appears in the list as a downloadable PDF.

Generate Report (3)

The final output reflects all required incident details, including custom and standard fields, in the WHS Form 10 format.

Output

 

4. Summary & Lessons Learned

Extensibility plays a critical role in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud implementations for Environment, Health, and Safety (EHS). As demonstrated throughout this blog post, even highly regulated processes such as incident reporting or country-specific compliance documentation can be effectively supported using SAP‚Äôs clean-core extensibility framework.

Drawing from our project experience and the two practical use cases presented, this chapter summarizes the key takeaways and highlights the most important lessons learned when implementing extensibility in EHS Public Cloud.

4.1 Key Takeaways

Clean-Core Extensibility Is Not a Limitation ‚Äì It is a Design Principle

The SAP Public Cloud model enforces strict boundaries around what can be extended. Rather than restricting customers, these boundaries ensure:

  • Long-term upgrade protection
  • Predictable lifecycle behavior
  • Lower maintenance effort
  • Full SAP supportability

All enhancements must therefore rely on SAP-released extension points.

Most EHS Requirements Can Be Solved with Key User Extensibility

A major insight from our implementations is that the majority of EHS use cases do not require developer extensibility or side-by-side applications.

Key User tools already cover:

  • Custom data fields
  • UI adaptations
  • PDF report adjustments
  • BAdI logic

Both examples in this blog were fully implemented using Key User Extensibility only.

BAdIs Are the Backbone of EHS Extensibility

SAP delivers a growing catalogue of EHS specific BAdIs in the Public Cloud, particularly for:

  • Incident Management
  • Emissions Management

Key lessons:

  • Each BAdI is designed for a very specific business context.
  • You often need to use several BAdIs together to populate a report for a form.
  • They enable retrieving structured data via released CDS Views and APIs.
  • Clean and modular implementations significantly improve maintainability.

Custom Forms Require a Structured Approach

Regulatory reports require a combination of:

  • A form template (Adobe)
  • Custom fields
  • BAdI logic
  • CBC configuration

The lesson: Form extensibility is not only a technical activity ‚Äì it is a cross-functional exercise involving business, logic, and configuration layers.

Configuration in SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC) / Implementation Activities is Essential

EHS reporting relies heavily on CBC / Implementation Activities, especially when assigning:

  • Forms > form groups
  • Form groups > regulations
  • Regulations > incident categories

A common project challenge: Without correct CBC (or Implementation Activities) configuration, even perfectly implemented forms and BAdIs will not appear in the UI.

End-to-End Testing Is Crucial

Because EHS extensions span UI, logic, reporting and configuration layers, testing must always validate the entire lifecycle:

  • Incident creation > processing > regulation selection > report generation

This avoids fragmented testing and ensures that all extension layers work together seamlessly.

4.2 Lessons Learned

Start With the Simplest Possible Extension Option

Always begin with Key User tools before considering Developer Extensibility or SAP BTP. Public Cloud projects succeed when complexity is added only where absolutely necessary.

Choose BAdIs Wisely ‚Äì Don‚Äôt Over-Engineer

Each BAdI serves a narrow purpose. Trying to force a single BAdI to solve multiple needs often causes issues later. Modular, purpose-aligned implementations are easier to maintain and debug.

Document Custom Logic and Configuration Thoroughly

Because Public Cloud enforces strict structure, even small enhancements should be:

  • Named consistently (YY1_*)
  • Documented cleanly (purpose, input, output)
  • Readable for team members who join the project later.

Well-documented extensions also reduce future rework during audits or regulatory updates.

Maintain a Strong Governance Around Extensibility

Typical governance measures include:

  • Reviewing whether a need truly requires an extension
  • Maintaining a central register of custom fields and BAdIs
  • Ensuring no duplicate fields are created
  • Enforcing naming conventions

This prevents uncontrolled growth of extensions over time.

Engage Business Users Early in the Design Process

EHS professionals often know exactly how regulations should be represented. Early involvement helps:

  • Avoid unnecessary extensions
  • Validate report layouts
  • Confirm the accuracy of populated data
  • Ensure usability in real operational scenarios

Plan for Future Regulatory Requirements

EHS compliance evolves frequently. When building extensions, always think ahead:

  • Could this field or form be reused for another regulation?
  • Can we structure the logic to accommodate more categories in the future?
  • Are we using modular BAdI implementations that can scale?

This significantly reduces technical dept.

4.3 Best Practices

To close this chapter, here is a consolidated best-practice checklist:

  • Use SAP-released extension points only (clean core).
  • Prefer Key User Extensibility for EHS whenever possible.
  • Keep BAdI implementations modular and business-context specific.
  • Use functional naming conventions for fields, forms, and BAdIs.
  • Perform end-to-end lifecycle testing (UI > logic > form > CBC).
  • Document every extension early, including purpose and data sources.
  • Reuse released CDS Views and APIs ‚Äì never rely on unreleased objects.
  • Involve business users early to ensure regulatory accuracy.
  • Build form templates in a future-proof, scalable structure.
  • Maintain strong governance to avoid unnecessary or duplicate extensions.

4.4 Final Remark

Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is not about pushing technical boundaries. It is about using the right tools to deliver business value while protecting system integrity. With a structured approach, as illustrated in both examples, customers can achieve regulatory compliance, process optimization, and system flexibility without compromising the clean-core principles that define the Public Cloud.

 

 

5. Engage with Us

To follow the series, make sure to subscribe to the SAP EHS Public Cloud blog tag.

We welcome your thoughts and feedback in the comments!

This blog post series is the result of close collaboration within our EHS implementation team. I would like to express my sincere appreciation to my colleagues, whose expertise, insights, and project experience significantly contributed to the depth and quality of this guide.
